content.rendered:
Without a premeditated desire to choose only Asian restaurants, we have three Asian restaurant identities this week with work from Chihuahua, Vancouver, and Brooklyn.

Bōru by Folklore

Bōru is a sushi restaurant in Chihuahua, Mexico, that also specializes in giant rice balls stuffed with sushi stuff, which is a nice metaphor for the restaurant’s identity by local firm Folklore: They have stuffed Asian references in a funky vernacular tone of voice filled to the brim with crappy (on purpose) illustrations of Pokémons, Kaiju, and who-knows-what-else. It has a lowbrow vibe but with a strong grid holding it all together. The logo is cool and by being solid, bold shapes it stands out from all the stuff around it and helps anchor all the wackiness. See full project

Torafuku by Brief

Torafuku is a pan Asian restaurant in Vancouver with a contemporary farm-to-table approach. The identity by local firm Brief reflects the contrast of traditional and contemporary with a range of classic patterns designed in thick lines and and presented in a vibrant palette of primary colors with a pastel hue. The patterns get emblazoned with a gold foil logo and are used as liners throughout the materials. My favorite aspect of this project, however, is the use of the colors in various elements of the restaurant, from the trays to the rubber bands in the menus to decorations like the water bottles and picture frames shown above. It’s a great way to extend an identity through physical objects. Another bonus is the restaurant’s website, which is remarkably simple, nice, and integrates all the elements perfectly. See full project

Kimski by Franklyn

Kimski is a fusion restaurant in Chicago, IL, serving Polish and Korean street food and the result looks a little something like this. Damn, right? The identity by Brooklyn, NY-based Franklyn is as epically fusionized as the food with a very out-there combination of Eastern-Bloc-style graphics and some other indefinable style that renders pickles, sausages, dumplings, humans, and more in an eclectic way. The logo is set in a monospace typeface to offset everything else and it makes sense in not making much sense but when it all looks this much fun, what’s sense got to do it? See full project
